In our recent class discussion, we delved into the assigned reading, 'Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World' by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter, 'Implacement,' and the second, 'Displacement,' offered a fascinating exploration of the concepts that shape our understanding of the world. Casey posits that our contemporary culture and society are dominated by the force of time, which he argues is a situating force that drives our daily lives. We are constantly racing against time, trying to make the most of the hours we have, and yet, paradoxically, we are often stuck in the present moment. Casey's central argument is that by placing place at the forefront of our cultural considerations, we can cultivate a more grounded sense of community and belonging. This book has had a profound impact on me, as it is the first reading to have truly resonated with me and sparked a deeper appreciation for the importance of place in shaping our experiences.

I find the concept of flag-burning laws to be quite misguided. As a non-American blogger, I've been hesitant to engage in certain discussions, particularly those revolving around the flag-burning debate. However, since I've been drawn into it, I feel compelled to share my thoughts. In my opinion, the notion of automatically bestowing legal protection upon a symbol, regardless of its meaning or perceived significance, is a slippery slope towards authoritarianism. Symbols can be fleeting and context-dependent, and their meaning is often shaped by the way they are perceived or intentionally designed to convey. It's crucial to recognize that symbols, in and of themselves, do not inherently possess inherent meaning; it's the meaning we assign to them that truly matters.

While they may provide additional story context, the combat mechanics feel clumsy and lack the finesse of Arkham City's more refined approach. As of the time of writing this recommendation (October 26, 2013), a game-breaking bug persists, which prevents a key side mission from ever being completed (the main story remains unaffected). Some gadgets are inconveniently mapped to a hotkey, requiring an arduous journey across the keyboard to access them. Although it may seem minor, this issue can potentially disrupt combat and even break your combo.

The Shadow Warrior (2013) is a game that has made significant strides in terms of boss battles, weapon handling, and enemy difficulty. The boss fights are truly exceptional, with weapons that feel incredibly satisfying to wield (although they may not quite match the quality of the D44M weapons, they are still solid options). The enemies are not overly simplistic, requiring a good understanding of elemental weaknesses and upgrade mechanics to overcome. The upgrade system is well-balanced, making it easy to progress without becoming too tedious. The limited ammo and elemental weaknesses of each weapon encourage the use of a diverse arsenal, which is refreshing and adds to the game's replay value. The soundtrack is excellent, with the main theme and Stan Bush's contributions being particularly noteworthy.

The Assassin's Creed series nailed the mechanics down on all fronts, from ship battles to sailing, hunting, and parkour. I felt a strong emotional connection to this character as well. The story begins rough, but it improves significantly as you progress, much like every other action game I've played. Edward was an intriguing character, as were the supporting characters. I felt that all the collectibles had a meaningful purpose in this game, which I didn't get from any of the previous ones. Perhaps it's because I felt like they had a greater significance in the game. They were not essential, but they were enjoyable to collect and were rewarded in a well-balanced manner.

While I personally cannot wholeheartedly recommend this game, it wasn't entirely terrible. The gunplay is passable, provided you're willing to invest in purchasing gun parts, which is my primary criticism with this game  it's a pay-to-win model. If I could look past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and the HRV system is an excellent concept. I'd choose this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransactions format is off-putting for me. If you're comfortable with this model, then by all means, have fun. However, if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, I would advise against it; it's not my cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been a thoroughly enjoyable experience. However, the save system and the possibility of sudden death can lead to some frustration, particularly during the early stages of the game. I experienced this firsthand when I lost my main character around the 10th hour of my 20-hour playthrough. A save feature to reload at that point would have been greatly appreciated. Fortunately, I've since discovered a third-party mod/save tool to mitigate the risk of catastrophic failures. Additionally, the aiming reticle could be slightly larger and the zoom function could be more powerful. Despite these minor drawbacks, I've thoroughly enjoyed my time with the game. As someone who doesn't typically play zombie-themed games, I've found the combination of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat-em-up elements to be particularly engaging. I've found myself playing it as often as I can get away, often getting sucked into just one more mission or supply run before reluctantly shutting the game down.

This game is an absolute masterpiece of strategy! Having played every other war game (European Escalation, and Alpha), I have to say that this one stands out. The sheer number of units is impressive. Although I'm not entirely sure how many units there are, there's an astonishing amount. The graphics are stunning, the sounds are fantastic, and the gameplay is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is also highly entertaining, I'm not exaggerating. However, if you think this game is 'easy' or if you're new to the strategy genre, it may take some time to master. Don't get discouraged if you lose units - it's all part of the learning process. Just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air and anti-tank capabilities to increase your chances of success.

I was initially skeptical about this game before I played it. I was unsure about purchasing it, especially given the portal gun and portal concept, which seemed unusual to me, despite my appreciation for science fiction. However, I was pleasantly surprised. The humor and voice acting in this game are phenomenal. They are not cheesy, and the different characters have distinct personalities. Each one has a unique sense of humor, which adds to the game's charm. The level design is also impressive, with its unique blend of challenging and fun elements. I never played the first Portal game, but I'm planning to play it soon if I can find the time. In fact, I wouldn't have played it if I hadn't played the sequel, as the experience has made me curious about the original game.

Embark on a nostalgic journey with this delightful trip down memory lane, as thirty-somethings who grew up in the UK can relive the excitement of watching the ever-iconic Transformers cartoon, featuring the memorable voice acting talents of Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many more. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound effects are instantly recognizable, transporting you back to a bygone era. Graphically, the cel-shaded presentation is a masterclass in nostalgic charm, exuding a sense of retro flair that is undeniably Generation 1. Beyond its retro aesthetic, the game is an absolute blast, boasting combat mechanics that are nothing short of exceptional. The seamless integration of mid-fight transformations, expertly woven into fluid combos, sets it apart from other Cybertron games. Another notable distinction is the emphasis on melee combat, which is expertly balanced by the inclusion of ranged blasters for those who prefer a more strategic approach, as seen in encounters with formidable foes like the Seekers.

I recently downloaded the game and spent a brief period playing it, but unfortunately, it failed to impress me. The login process was more time-consuming than the actual gameplay, as I encountered a recurring issue where the "update to terms of service" prompt would repeatedly appear, requiring me to restart the client to progress. This is somewhat inconvenient, especially since I was asked to link my Steam and GFace accounts, citing the need for downloadable content (DLC). However, this linking is not reversible, which means that a company I'm not familiar with now has access to my Steam information. In terms of the game itself, I found it to be a noticeable clone of another game, with the added disappointment of subpar gunplay. It's astonishing that the developers managed to make it worse, as it's clear that they had the potential to do better.

Enjoy a stunning 4K+ experience at 60 frames per second with a GTX 970, accompanied by dual audio options and the inclusion of Neptune Gear. What's not to love? This exceptional port is an excellent entry point for newcomers to the series. Please note that there is some (skippable) dialogue, which may be a consideration for some players. As always, I recommend using a gamepad, but I had no issues with a keyboard and mouse setup, which is fully customizable. The price is reasonable, and I wouldn't have hesitated to make a purchase. Moreover, over half of the DLC is included at no additional cost, providing ample content to enjoy. I highly recommend this game to fans of JRPGs, anime, and visual novels, provided you're willing to tolerate occasional breaks between action sequences. Cheers! For those who prefer commentary-free gameplay, I've created a playlist available here  https //www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLSLFVijaUpsZeZ9Af395MvNk63XnHsj1

I was impressed by the seamless performance, even at the initial release, and following numerous patches, the game plays exceptionally well. In my opinion, this is a truly exceptional and entertaining game, although the format may be slightly unconventional (where the free-roam city area respawns with new enemies every time you progress through the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play as both Batman and Robin), and the ability to use the controller for most parts of the game, while employing the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving the Batmobile around the free-roam city, including when pursuing the Arkham City Commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you master the art of using the brakes to drift around corners (and when you master that, driving around the city is truly quite enjoyable).

I'm not a native English speaker, as my native language is Dutch. Please bear with any minor typos or grammatical errors in my review of this fantastic game. I'll break down my review into several categories  Graphics, Controls, Sound, and Replayability. Graphics  The game's visuals are set in a comic-like style, with very detailed and vibrant color schemes. The graphics can be set to 'high' without straining your system's resources. I play this game on an i5 processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M graphics card and 8GB of RAM, running Windows 8.1, and it runs seamlessly. Controls  The game can be played using a keyboard and mouse, but it's also compatible with an Xbox controller.

You can see the countless hours I've invested in this game, and it's clear that I thoroughly enjoy it. This is exactly what I had hoped for in a search game from CD Projekt Red - a game that truly understands the concept of immersion and execution. Don't make the mistake of buying this game thinking it's like Call of Duty, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's a game that stands in its own league and deserves to be treated as such. I've lost count of how many new players I've seen complaining about getting killed quickly, only to be met with the same tired 'oh no, I got shot in the face and died' refrain. It's not like that kind of thing happens in real life or anything. After spending a considerable amount of time playing this game, I can confidently say it's one of the best multiplayer games out there. It's a great option to play when you're not in the mood for CS GO.

I'm two hours in and I'm dying from laughing so hard at this game. The gameplay is solid, the art design is breathtakingly beautiful, the music is surprisingly high-quality and perfectly fitting, the story/world has me thoroughly engaged, and the puzzles are delightfully entertaining. But the most remarkable aspect of this game is its comedy. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video game RPGs, you'll be in stitches at the numerous jokes, parodies, and references; if you're new to RPGs, you'll still appreciate the game's humor. If you played Final Fantasy VII or X, you absolutely must play this game, without giving away too much - I had to pause my playtime after two hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so uncontrollably. What a sheer delight so far.

I'm truly sorry to say, I was genuinely enthusiastic about supporting free-to-play games and independent developers, but unfortunately, this game failed to meet my expectations. The game's description initially piqued my interest, but the execution fell short in several key areas. As a lover of puzzle and exploration games, I was underwhelmed by the experience, as I found the gameplay to be unnecessarily complicated and frustrating. Moreover, the lack of a pause button was a glaring oversight, particularly given the time-sensitive nature of certain sequences in the game. This oversight made it even more difficult to fully engage with the game, and I often found myself simply sitting idly, waiting for the time to pass. Furthermore, I believe the game is more of a proof-of-concept than a fully fleshed-out game, and I spent a significant amount of time simply waiting for something to happen.

This game was an absolute masterpiece, from its captivating storyline to its stunning graphics, I was completely enthralled. The narrative was more than just a story; it felt as if I was the protagonist, trying to unravel the mystery that my character was recounting. The gameplay was exceptional, and I discovered a lot about myself through this game - primarily, my fear of heights, which I never previously experienced until the ice caverns. My stomach churned throughout the entire experience, but I persisted, driven by my determination to see what lay ahead, all for Uncle Fred! If you were to create a downloadable content pack or a sequel, I would be the first in line to purchase it and enthusiastically recommend it to everyone I know. A huge thank you to everyone involved in creating this masterpiece, you have crafted a truly breathtaking game.

Beyond Earth, the latest installment in the Sid Meier's Civilization series, is a turn-based game where you guide your civilization's evolution to achieve a specific objective or 'victory'. Unlike previous games in the series, which spanned the Earth's timeline through various eras such as the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Era, this game takes a bold leap into the future by setting you on a mission to colonize a new planet. I appreciate the innovative approach taken by the developers, which introduced fresh mechanics such as the Affinity System and Orbital Layer. However, I found that these new mechanics sometimes led to an overwhelming experience. To further enhance the game, I believe that incorporating updated artwork, particularly the environmental elements encountered during interactions with other leaders, could greatly improve the overall gameplay experience.

It's a shame I can't thoroughly recommend or fully enjoy this game, given the short time I've played it. I know I'd be hooked if it didn't have the following two game-breaking issues. Firstly, the lack of Aussie servers is a major drawback, as one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and creates unbearable lag. Moreover, I played through the offline training mode, and it was stuttering and lagging as well - a phenomenon that defies explanation. Coupled with the poor ping, it's just unbearable. Additionally, the game's assets, such as the menus, backgrounds, and in-game graphics, are laughable, with everything appearing as if it's in a state of disarray. I've never experienced this issue with this card before, and I thought it might not be compatible with my graphics processing unit. I set my GPU back to stock settings, and, sure enough, it didn't make a difference.

The recently completed game was a satisfying experience. Although the story may not have been particularly complex or captivating, the narrative's engaging atmosphere and numerous collectibles effectively brought it to life. I gained valuable insight into the world of Batman, although I was slightly underwhelmed by the limited number of boss battles. Fortunately, there are promising future games that will likely rectify this. The combat, while not overly challenging, strikes a good balance between accessibility and difficulty. Leveling up Batman was not overly fulfilling, but the gadgets and upgrades I acquired during the campaign added a welcome layer of depth to the gameplay. Gaining access to previously inaccessible areas was a satisfying aspect of the game, providing a sense of progression and accomplishment.

To venture to the moon is no mere escapism... Nay, it's a transcendent experience, and it was one of the most profound and exhilarating experiences of my life to date. Think Telltale's The Walking Dead is sad? Ah, it's no match for the moon! Never before have I been so deeply moved and fulfilled by something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the apex of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a ravishingly charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls can be a bit finicky, and the gameplay is not the strong suit, but the story is so captivating that I didn't care one bit. Moreover, the humor is expertly woven throughout, never intruding upon the distinguished nature of the narrative. And the doctor's references are endless, adding a layer of depth and complexity to the already rich tapestry of the game.

The bastion is a remarkably brilliant game, boasting a captivating storyline. Following a catastrophic event, you begin to rebuild on the bastion, with a plethora of choices available to you, including the selection of which structures to construct for a strategic advantage, which weapons to wield, and what power-ups to equip on those weapons, as well as which elixirs to consume for a bonus effect. The artistic style and soundtrack in the game are exceptional, rendering everything visually stunning at times, making it difficult to imagine a more apocalyptic setting. Moreover, the game features a narrative that is heavily influenced by the player's actions, so if you opt to pick up a weapon and subsequently switch to another in the armory, the narrative will reflect your decision, describing your choice of weapon as you move forward.

I had initially acquired this game in its early development phase, when the primary currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree' in place. During this period, I found the game to be enjoyable. All the weapons at this stage were equally overpowered, resulting in a lack of balance; anyone could eliminate anyone at any moment. Additionally, the game initially provided unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. One might assume that, given the vast array of 'bajillions of guns', the developers would have offered more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring additional payment. In reality, I had amassed a collection of approximately three pages worth of firearms, and was exploring new ideas for expansion, as I found it most enjoyable when I had a surplus of options. This experience led me to believe that the game's developers could have done better in terms of providing a more balanced gameplay experience.

This game was a delightful surprise. The reviews of certain products are often misleading, but in this case, the reviews accurately reflect the enjoyable experience of this charming game. It's an intriguing blend of a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, executed with style. I found myself growing attached to characters I wouldn't typically enjoy in other MOBA games. Initially, I was skeptical about the melee tank, but was pleasantly surprised by the outcome and ended up trying out more characters as they became available through playing games. The art style and interface are delightfully charming. As a result, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I've recently discovered a captivating game that has consumed me for hours on end, completely immersed in its immersive atmosphere. The audio design, including the music and sound effects, perfectly complements the gameplay, while the controls are finely tuned to provide a seamless experience. Each combat encounter is a thrilling experience, and the ability to engage in simultaneous battles with multiple fleets is a game-changer. Initially, I had some reservations about the naval combat system, but I've found it to be an exhilarating aspect of the game. The only way to succumb to defeat is to fail to retreat and regroup, regroup, and counter-assault. The developers have done an outstanding job in crafting an experience that is both engaging and addictive.

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about a significant transformation for the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be disheartened by the change to their beloved character, it is undoubtedly for the better; and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. DMC serves as the ideal point for newcomers to jump into the series. It showcases the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear, narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to follow. The story follows Dante as he's introduced into the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore, presenting a complex and thought-provoking tale that explores the complexities of human nature.

Where do I start on this captivating game, which is an absolute delight? The story is an enchanting tale, overflowing with meticulous attention to detail, and overflowing with joy, witty humor, and endearing quirks. It strikes a perfect balance between seriousness and playfulness, effortlessly weaving together poignant moments with humorous ones. The character designs are expertly crafted, with a diverse array of characters boasting unique personalities and intriguing backstories. What sets this game apart from others is its refreshing departure from the typical RPG formula, where you're not forced to engage in violence or combat, which is a welcome departure from the norm in the RPG genre. Drawing inspiration from the esteemed Earthbound, one of the most exceptional RPGs I've had the pleasure of playing, it's clear that this game is destined to be a standout. The soundtrack is, without a doubt, one of the most memorable and captivating I've had the pleasure of experiencing.

I am recommending this solely because it's free, and it may be a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game didn't resonate with me. Half the story relies heavily on shock value, and I didn't find myself emotionally invested in the narrative. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simplistic to elicit a reaction from me. The other half of the game attempts to paint a vivid picture of a person's mental decline, exploring themes such as obsession, hallucinations, depression, and other related issues. While the concept is intriguing, I found the experience to be underwhelming, taking around 10 minutes to complete, which is excessive considering the amount of information presented. Despite this, I appreciate the game's attempt to tackle complex themes, but I didn't find it to be a particularly impactful or engaging experience.

Here is a polished version of the original text:

"Is it really necessary to elaborate on why Portal is an extraordinary game? Portal is a puzzle game that initially presents a concept and then gradually unfolds. It is an innovative way to challenge your cognitive abilities while still being an entertaining experience. Although this game may not have a rich narrative, it gave rise to one of the most beloved games of 2011. I still enjoy playing this game and return to it when I'm feeling underwhelmed and I relish the opportunity to revisit the puzzle-solving experience and see what contributed to its legendary status. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is surprisingly straightforward, yet deceptively complex. You utilize portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate specific puzzle elements. Two buttons are present in the game, one that you press and one that requires a cube to be applied.

I must admit that I encountered a couple of minor issues, but the bugs were easily resolved, resulting in a significant boost to my frame rate, which increased from 60-90 to 80-120 frames per second. If you're in the market for a space exploration game, I can wholeheartedly recommend this setup. Since most reviews focus on technical specifications, I'll provide my own  i5-6600k processor, Radeon RX 480 graphics card, Z170 Pro gaming monitor, 16GB DDR4 RAM, and a total budget of approximately 650. While this setup is on the higher end of the medium price range, it's still a relatively new system. Notably, I achieved a consistent 60+ frames per second on high settings with vsync enabled, which is a testament to the capabilities of this rig. I'm astonished that 90% of the comments claim they're running an overkill setup and still achieving only 20 frames per second.

Remember, the age of mythology? Yes, it's been a long time since there's been an RTS game of such exceptional quality. Divinity  Dragon Commander reaches awfully close to the borders of my personal most favorite RTS game. Combine this with a massive, risk-like grand strategy mode, and it hits the spot. I'm not (read  try not to be) overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to transform into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning at the very same time. Honestly, I do like the complex RTS games nowadays. Think of Civilization V and so on. However, such games attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources all into one complicated game mode.

Undertale comes together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics and music harmonize perfectly, crafting a nostalgic atmosphere that elevates the overall experience. The script masterfully navigates a wide range of emotions, effortlessly blending comedy, drama, heartbreak, and hope, often converging these elements in a single moment. This masterful storytelling approach turns RPG tropes on their head, creating a truly impactful and unforgettable experience. While the game's world, characters, story, and gameplay mechanics are all noteworthy, I could write an exhaustive analysis of each. Instead, I'll simply say this  if you're a fan of RPGs, you owe it to yourself to play this game. If you're a gamer, you won't want to miss this experience. If you have seven free hours before your mortality, seize the opportunity to indulge in this remarkable game.

I've had the privilege of playing this game for only a few months, but in that short span of time, not two, but three DLCs have been released, along with patches that have elevated an already excellent game to an exceptional one. The developers are incredibly active in the community, and it's evident in the various discussion forums and developer diaries. The game's mechanics can be complex, with a steep learning curve that I'm still navigating; however, this depth of strategy offers a multitude of ways to achieve goals and capitalize on specific situations. In my opinion, the game is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself becoming completely absorbed in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough unfolds.

Warframe is an engaging game that initially offers a thrilling experience for a few hours of play. However, as the hours pass, the repetitive nature of the combat, enemies, and gameplay becomes apparent. The redeeming factor is the dedication of the developers, who consistently release regular updates that introduce significant changes, new warframes, and other improvements to the game's systems. This dedication ensures that the game remains enjoyable for casual players. While it may not retain its appeal beyond a few months for dedicated players, it is a worthwhile experience worth trying out. As a bonus, the game is free, making it an accessible option for those seeking a quick fix or a casual gaming experience.

This game is a crushing disappointment. I was underwhelmed by my purchase of this game, which I thought was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a popular and charming PS2 game. Unfortunately, it falls short of my expectations. In this game, you find yourself absorbing increasingly massive objects to grow larger and absorb even more enormous entities. However, the gameplay is marred by rough edges, with levels that lack imagination and a surreal horror show that leaves you questioning the meaning of existence. I don't mean a thrilling horror show, but one that leaves you feeling melancholic and makes you wonder if being alive is all it's cracked up to be. Every living creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, raises the question whether the creators of this game have an interest in taxidermy.

Alright, let me explain a few things as a person deeply interested in politics. I was very intrigued when I first heard about this game, thinking, 'Wow, a simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds exciting!' However, it didn't quite live up to my expectations. The game starts by asking you to choose a side  Republican or Democrat, with no option for an independent or third party. A little disappointed, but still optimistic, I decided to continue playing to see what I could do. I will give the game credit, the character customization, although limited, is quite enjoyable to play around with. It's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign. Literally.

The Fallout 3 story suffers from poor settlement design, which can be frustrating to the point where you'll find yourself baby-sitting them instead of progressing through the story. Some features are hardcoded and cannot be rebound. Bugs are abundant. My Pip-Boy disappeared permanently at one point, and I had to research console commands to recover it. You don't have to work for power armor; it's essentially given to you from the beginning of the game, and power cores are abundant in trader shops. The value of power armor has diminished significantly from previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre, with everything about this game being average, except that it doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3. Compared to Fallout 3, it's relatively stable. While it's not better than Fallout 3, it's not terrible either. This title was overhyped for how mediocre it actually is.

My gaming experience with this title was a mixed bag, with a total playtime of 8.6 hours to reach the end. During this time, I managed to collect 10 out of 25 collectibles and earn zero achievements out of 15. What I enjoyed most about the game was the visuals, which remained engaging until the very end, particularly the ice caves level. While the story wasn't particularly impressive, the conclusion after the credits was satisfying enough to make me feel like I didn't regret spending my time playing this game. On the other hand, the visuals in the final level were underwhelming, and the gameplay became frustratingly repetitive in its repetition, making it a chore to complete. Furthermore, the achievements were excessively challenging, with only 13 (out of 15) achieved by less than 2.1% of players, making it a challenging experience for many players.

The game has its pros and cons. On the plus side, the graphics are commendable. However, there are some significant drawbacks. One major issue is the numerous bugs, particularly in the environment, which can cause frustration when you get stuck or your shots hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight on the enemy. Another issue is the handholding/babysitting nature of the game, which can be annoying. The AI is also quite dumb, making it easy for enemies to locate you when you're spotted. The enemy's accuracy is almost godlike, which can be frustrating, similar to the first Ghost Warrior. Additionally, the checkpoints and save system are subpar. The story is also underwhelming, and I found it difficult to care about it. Unless it's 90% off, I wouldn't recommend it. Even then, playing this game feels like an extremely boring chore, and I only play it to finish it to move on to the next game in my library. Considering the time I wasted on the first Ghost Warrior, which was equally underwhelming, I probably won't play this game until the end.

Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? This puzzle-platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who goes around collecting little bits to form a cube and navigating through a fairly large, branching map. The game is quite amusing and running through it to complete the game was quite a bit of fun. However, it can become semi-frustrating if you want to get all the cubes and achievements, as you'll need to crack codes that you'll have to decipher. These can take a few seconds or frustrate you into looking into a guide. To get all the cubes, you'll need to crack the codes, which can be a bit challenging. Nonetheless, with persistence and patience, you'll eventually get there. The guide, 'A Complete Guide to Fetz,' can be a helpful resource for those who need a little extra assistance.

It's not difficult for me to see why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. One thing I have is a preference for more immersive, room-scale gaming experiences with controllers. Beyond the game's awe-inspiring universe scale, I felt that same scale hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and the time required to do anything engaging at the beginning were too steep for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time to dedicate to gaming, this might be more appealing to me. However, I lack the luxury of time and there are numerous other VR games I'd rather devote my time to.

Hands down, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. The need for run-and-gun rambos is a thing of the past. Recoil and ballistics are remarkably realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it merely grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are essential if you wish to maintain a steady aim. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload halfway through your magazine, you'll find yourself with a pouch full of half-full mags. You can't sustain a sprint indefinitely. If you sprint for a while, your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you've caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a windowsill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing, as the human body is not designed for sustained, prolonged periods of rapid movement.

I would like to begin by stating that I did not purchase E.U. when it initially launched and instead, I acquired it on sale, which included E.W. I never experienced the issues that some players claim to have encountered with that game. I thoroughly enjoyed the game, despite its unforgiving nature in the early stages, which only made it more rewarding when I executed actions correctly. As for XCOM 2, I have a strong affection for it, and the game runs smoothly on medium settings on my system, which consists of a GTX 560 with 2GB of video RAM. Initially, the game was set to high settings, which resulted in a slightly sluggish performance, but not to the extent that it became unplayable. However, when I adjusted the settings to medium, the game ran smoothly without any issues. I'm not sure if I'm simply fortunate when it comes to avoiding problems with games or if it's a matter of circumstance, but it appears that most of the negative reviews seem to stem from an entitled mentality among some players.

This RPG game offers a wide variety of ship types, featuring physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles. The resource management system is easy to learn, allowing players to focus on the action. While the game may have some drawbacks, such as limited equipment options and a non-branching leveling system, it still offers a fun and engaging experience. The game starts off quickly and maintains a steady pace, making it easy to get into the action. The variety of ships and skills to unlock keeps things fresh and exciting, and the game's ability to be modded adds a whole new level of replayability. The combat is the main attraction, but the addition of challenging battles against powerful enemies is also a major draw. Overall, this game is a great option for fans of the genre, and the mods available can greatly enhance the experience.

Global leaders from over 2,000 business and political leaders from around the world are converging on the picturesque Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will engage in discussions on a wide range of pressing issues, including China's economic prowess and the future of Iraq after this Sunday's elections. Notable attendees include UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, among more than 20 government leaders and heads of state leaders. In a departure from previous years, protests against the WEW are expected to be subdued, as anti-globalization campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, scheduled to run concurrently with the WEW's more exclusive event in Davos.

As the clock ticks down, Fiat and General Motors (GM) are racing against the midnight deadline on February 1 to resolve their disagreement over a potential takeover. The agreement, initially struck in 2000, grants Fiat the right to sell its car division to GM, provided the impasse is resolved by the deadline. However, GM's own European operations are currently incurring losses, leading the company to reconsider its commitment to the unprofitable Fiat unit. Following reports of stalled negotiations, Fiat's shares plummeted 1.2% on Tuesday, reversing Monday's 4% surge, which was fueled by hopes of a successful resolution. GM is reportedly offering approximately $2 billion (1.06 billion) to extricate itself from the arrangement, citing Fiat's decision to divest its finance arm and reduce GM's stake through a capital-raising effort as grounds for voiding the deal. The 2000 alliance was born out of a competitive bidding war between GM and DaimlerChrysler to forge a partnership with Fiat.

In a scathing critique, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has lamented the staggering sum of billions of pounds spent on the Iraq War, urging that these funds would have been better allocated to alleviate poverty, malnutrition, and disease. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day segment, the head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales reiterated his strong stance against the war, describing it as a "terrible" waste of resources. The Cardinal's comments come on the heels of similar remarks made by the Archbishop of Canterbury, who has also spoken out against the conflict. In his Christmas message, Cardinal Murphy-O'Connor called for 2005 to be a year of "making history" by campaigning to eradicate poverty, rather than perpetuating a cycle of conflict. His remarks serve as a powerful reminder of the devastating human cost of war and the urgent need for more effective, compassionate, and sustainable solutions to global challenges.

Debra Hill, the renowned screenwriter and producer, best known for her work on the 1978 horror classic "Halloween," has passed away at the age of 54 in Los Angeles. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the iconic film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter tormented by a psychopath, under the direction of John Carpenter. The film's massive success, which grossed over $60 million worldwide, was a record-breaking achievement for an independent film at the time. Hill's impressive body of work also includes collaborations with Carpenter on "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and steadily worked her way up the ranks, eventually becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. Throughout her illustrious career, Hill was widely regarded as a trailblazing woman in the film industry, taking on roles in the 1970s that were often reserved for her male counterparts.

According to research, the widespread availability of broadband internet access is fuelling an explosion in online self-expression, with a quarter of British broadband users regularly uploading content and maintaining personal websites. The report by UK think-tank Demos highlights that having an always-on, fast connection is revolutionizing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and this figure is growing rapidly. The study examined the impact of broadband on people's online habits and found that over half of those with broadband log on to the web before breakfast. Moreover, one in five respondents admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the internet, underscoring the notion that broadband is empowering people to take a more proactive role online.

Yukos, the Russian oil and gas company, is set to face a US court on Thursday as it continues its fight for survival. The firm is currently being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27 billion tax bill. Yukos has filed for bankruptcy in the US, seeking to exploit international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was sold for $9.4 billion to state-owned oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction was disrupted. Yukos' lawyers now claim that the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any entity that acquires its assets, using all legal means at their disposal.

Voters are flocking to the blog awards website, where the annual Bloggies ceremony is underway, recognizing the best online weblogs that showcase the year's most thought-provoking and engaging content. The nominations were announced on Sunday, but the heavy traffic to the official site caused the website to temporarily shut down due to the overwhelming number of visitors. This year, weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. The blogosphere has had a remarkable year, with the term "blog" being named as the Word of the Year in 2004 by a leading dictionary. According to Technorati, a prominent blog search engine, there are approximately six million blogs online, with over 12,000 new ones being added daily. Interestingly, a new blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to research by the Pew Internet and American Life project. However, only less than 40% of these blogs are updated at least once every two months, highlighting the dynamic nature of this ever-evolving online landscape.

Despite defying a government directive, the Chinese company, Beijing Three Gorges Project Corp, is continuing construction on its Xiluodu Dam, according to a report by the Chinese State Press. The company is ignoring a government order to halt construction on one of its massive projects, which is part of a larger group of 30 large-scale construction projects ordered to be suspended due to inadequate environmental assessments. The Beijing News reported that the company may instead opt to pay a fine for non-compliance. Additionally, the firm has disregarded orders to cease construction at two other projects, the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. As of now, only 22 of the 30 projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with the shutdown order.

Manchester United's 0-2 defeat to Manchester City was a scrappy and hard-fought victory for the Red Devils, as they claimed nine points in the Premier League table. Wayne Rooney's clinical finish was the highlight of the match, as he met Gary Neville's cross with a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne and found the back of the net. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne's volley over David James' head and into his own net brought the game back to 1-2. Steve McManaman had Manchester City's best chance when he shot wide from just three yards out in the first half. Despite a laboured approach, United managed to create just one chance, a Paul Scholes header that sailed over the bar. The Red Devils' performance in the opening 45 minutes was far from convincing, but they managed to keep the pressure on Chelsea and maintain any hope of catching their opponents in the title race.

Wales Must Draw Health Lessons from England, Says New Health Minister

As Wales' new Health Minister, Dr. Brian Gibbons, began his tenure, he acknowledged that there are valuable lessons to be learned from England's approach to tackling waiting lists. On his first full day in office, following the departure of Jane Hutt, Dr. Gibbons described the challenges ahead as "big," but emphasized that the fundamentals were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats called for a policy shift, urging Dr. Gibbons to adopt a new strategy. Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her record, arguing that waiting times and lists comprised only a small fraction  10%  of the broader health agenda.

Sir Alex Ferguson has lauded the Manchester United players for their resilient performance in their 1-0 win against Aston Villa, describing it as the team's most challenging away game of the season. 'That was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end, with lots of good passing,' Ferguson said. 'We showed a lot of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come and Aston Villa may have some players back when they do.' Ferguson also praised senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. 'Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield, which no other player has got.'

The upcoming Berlin Film Festival will feature a documentary about the life of chart-topping singer George Michael, which offers a candid look at his remarkable career and personal life. The documentary, which will be screened in the Panorama section of the festival, will showcase Michael discussing his early days in Wham! and his later career, including his legal battles with Sony and his stance on the Iraq War and American politics. The 93-minute film will be introduced by George Michael himself on February 16. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also be in attendance at the festival. The documentary will run from February 10-20, offering a unique glimpse into the life and career of this iconic singer.

Downloads of singles chart digital music downloads are now being integrated into the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's Boulevard of Broken Dreams currently sits at number two on Billboard's Pop chart, and tops its digital chart. The incorporation of download sales into the US singles chart is expected to occur later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be combined with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new Hot 100 chart. The second new chart, the Pop 100, also combines airplay, digital, and physical sales, but confines its airplay data to US radio stations that play chart music.

Optinrealbig.com, the self-proclaimed spam king, is seeking bankruptcy protection as the company, led by Scott Richter, faces significant financial difficulties. The company, which has been involved in several legal battles, including a notable lawsuit against Microsoft, is now seeking to restructure its debt through a chapter 11 bankruptcy filing. This move is seen as a strategic attempt to resolve the company's legal issues while still allowing it to continue operating. As the third-largest spammer in the world, according to the junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, Optinrealbig has faced numerous legal challenges. In 2003, the company was sued by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Scott Richter and his associates sent billions of spam messages to 514 compromised email addresses in 35 countries. The lawsuit was a result of Optinrealbig's alleged violation of anti-spam laws, which led to a significant backlash from the online community.

Arnesen has denied any rift with Santini, Tottenham's sporting director, and has dismissed reports that he resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. According to Arnesen, the reports are 'absolutely not true', and he has spoken with Santini recently, who attributed his departure to his own personal problems. 'It's not true,' Arnesen told BBC Radio 5 Live. 'There's only one thing that made him resign, and that's his own personal problems.' Arnesen refused to comment on the specific issues that led to Santini's departure after just 13 games in charge. He did, however, acknowledge that Santini had never publicly disclosed the reasons behind his decision, but emphasized that he respected the situation. 'I think we should respect it,' Arnesen said.

Ireland's six-nation grand slam ambitions were bolstered by an impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield, with a commanding 24-0 lead by half-time. Hugo Southwell's early try gave the Scots an 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in control. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-fought away wins, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will strive to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy comes to Edinburgh, but they struggled to turn pressure into points.

The Chancellor has stated that the focus of the election campaign will be the economy, with the future of Britain's economic stability and growth at its core. This was announced after a meeting of Cabinet members at 10 Downing Street prior to the election announcement. The Chancellor emphasized that voters will recognize that Labour has brought stability and growth, and will continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Conservative Party outlined their plans to address the 'yob culture' issue, and the Liberal Democrats provided more information about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties, urging them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime. In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about these issues.

This weekend, a talented group of eight Irish athletes will represent Ireland at the European Indoor Championships in Sheffield, with sprinter Paul Brizzel among them. Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far, with Brizzel set to defend his 200m title in the British trials. Meanwhile, James McIlroy will look to secure his place in the British team for the Europeans by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in exceptional form on the European circuit in recent weeks, and his speed and endurance have made him a strong contender for a spot in the Madrid team. In a mid-week confirmation, Mark Carroll revealed that he will join Cragg in the European Championships, with the duo aiming to make a strong impression on the international stage. Carroll, currently ranked third in the world 3000m ranking, will be a key player for the Irish team, alongside Cragg, who tops the world rankings.

England's dual-code star, Jason Robinson, has set his sights on dual-code success against Australia on Saturday. As a former rugby league international, Robinson has switched codes in 2000 and will lead England against Australia at Twickenham at 1 30pm GMT. England will look to seal their third autumn international victory, following consecutive wins over Canada and South Africa, and exact revenge for their 51-15 hammering by the Wallabies in June. Beating the Australians in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league, and England have the chance to put an end to 34 years of failure against Australia with a victory at Elland Road.

Warning  Be cautious of a potentially fraudulent website claiming to collect donations on behalf of tsunami victims. The website appears legitimate at first glance, as it is using an outdated version of the official disaster relief committee's webpage. However, it has no affiliation with the official site and has not contacted the authorities about it. This is just the latest in a long list of scams that attempt to capitalize on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam email with a subject line that reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal" and its text is riddled with poor grammar and spelling mistakes, characteristic of many other phishing attempts. Be wary of such scams and do not fall prey to their fraudulent schemes.

Iraq invites phone licence bids from local, Arab and foreign companies to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. The ministry of communications has invited bids for two telephone licences, with the goal of increasing Iraq's very low telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to around 25% within the next 10 years. The successful bidder will partner with the Iraqi telecommunications and post company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to develop a highly visible and changeable telecommunications sector, with a road-show for investors scheduled in Amman, Jordan. The tender details will be published on the ministry's website on February 9. This move is expected to boost the country's telecommunications sector and enhance its global connectivity.

According to a two-year study, women are increasingly taking charge of protecting their home computers from malicious internet attacks, with the number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware attacks rising by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted by a leading internet security firm, reveals that security messages are reaching a diverse range of internet users. It is believed that 40% of those purchasing home network security software are retired individuals, a figure that has increased by an average of 13.2% over the past three years. Moreover, more retired women (53%) are buying security software than retired men, reflecting the shifting demographics and growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband internet connections pose to internet users.

Podcasting has revolutionized the way people consume digital music, allowing individuals to store up to 10,000 songs on their Apple iPod or other digital music players. However, podcasting has also led to an explosion of creative content, with an unpredictable array of producers creating audio content. The term "podcasting" originated from the Apple iPod, although it is not necessary to own one to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show, where podcasters can produce their own shows from the comfort of their own homes. All they require is a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet, making them accessible for free download and listening by others.

Andrea Levy's novel, "Small Island", has won the Whitbread Novel of the Year award. The author has now emerged as a strong favourite to win the overall prize after beating Booker Prize winner Alan Hollinghurst's "The Line of Beauty". Geraldine McCaughren has picked up the Children's Fiction award for the third time for "Not the End of the World". All the category winners go through to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries with it a 25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will meet up on January 25 to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.

Yukos, a Russian oil company, is set to take legal action against Baikal Finance Group, a little-known firm, in a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions for the $20 billion damages it claims it suffered due to the sale of Yuganskneftegas. Yukos will argue that Baikal and other parties involved in the sale ignored a US court order last week, which blocked the sale. The Russian government's decision to ignore the court order has raised questions about Baikal's motives for buying the unit. Russian newspapers have reported that Baikal, which purchased the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion rubles, 4.8 billion) on Sunday at a state-arranged auction, has strong ties with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts thrashed Livingston 2-1 in their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie, dominating the game from the outset. Lee Miller opened the scoring within the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from Jamie McAllister's expertly taken free kick. The Scottish midfielder himself scored the second goal when he met Saul Mikoliunas' precise cross at the back post, securing the win for the home side. Craig Easton headed in a contentious goal after an hour, but Hearts held their lead. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken's clumsy foul on Miller from 35 yards out, allowing McAllister to float the free kick into the Livi box, where Miller outjumped the static visiting defense to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead, with McAllister's pace and precision proving too much for the visitors to handle. Sun Microsystems has introduced a revolutionary pay-as-you-go service that empowers customers to harness the power of computing resources on a flexible, on-demand basis. This innovative offering, known as grid computing, allows users to rent computing power and storage capacity on a per-hour basis, with prices starting at just $1.53 per hour. The company likens grid computing to the development of electricity, suggesting that computing capacity is as essential a commodity as hardware and software. According to Sun's Chief Operating Officer, Jonathan Schwartz, "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly network computing event in California, highlighting the convenience and cost-effectiveness of the service.

Scotland's Justice Minister Jamie Jamieson has issued a stern warning to bigoted soccer fans, stating that she intends to take a firm stance against them, targeting those who engage in the most egregious forms of sectarianism by banning them from attending matches. The Minister praised Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing this long-standing issue. Jamieson emphasized that stopping the sectarian abuse linked to historic club rivalries is a key objective. Speaking ahead of the third Scottish Cup clash between Glasgow clubs at Hampden Park on Sunday, Jamieson reiterated the Scottish Government's commitment to tackling the problem. The sectarianism, which has been a significant challenge for the executive, has been a long-standing issue, with sections of both clubs' support bases being a focal point. Last week, Jamieson and First Minister Nicola Sturgeon met with representatives from both clubs to discuss the matter in more detail.

Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film, 'Beyond the Sea', at London's Leicester Square on Thursday. The film, directed and starring Kevin Spacey, is an homage to the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of Darin, who sings all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. 'This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent,' said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom, expressed her newfound admiration for Darin, saying, 'I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan.'

Leeds Carnegie RFC have made some significant changes to their squad ahead of their Friday fixture at Headingley. The team has brought in Newcastle Falcons' prop, Ed Kalman, and Tom McGee on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez has been named as the new hooker, one of four changes made by the coaching staff. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell have also been selected in the pack, with Kevin Sorrell coming in at outside centre. The game at Headingley has been given the go-ahead after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds Carnegie's team  Balshaw, Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements  Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMullan, Rock, Vickerman.

The future of the fixed line phone in your home may soon be an endangered species. According to research conducted by Nokia, the use of mobile phones is becoming increasingly prevalent, with more and more people relying on their mobile devices for every call they make or receive. In the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea, over 45 million people now only use a mobile phone. The study reveals that individuals opt for fixed-line phones due to the lower call charges, but most respondents believe that mobile devices are the future. The Nokia-sponsored research found that mobiles and fixed phones serve distinct purposes. Home phones are used for longer, more in-depth conversations, whereas mobiles are often used for shorter, more informal chats with friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents stated that they prefer their fixed phone because it is still more cost-effective than using a mobile.

Jrgen Melzer delivered a stunning upset, as second-seeded Andre Agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat in the quarter-finals of the SAP Open. Agassi was frequently outmaneuvered by Melzer's clever drop shots in San Jose, ultimately succumbing 6-3, 6-1. Meanwhile, defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick fought back to defeat Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Unseeded Cyril Saulnier pulled off a major upset by defeating fourth-seeded Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, while Tommy Haas overcame eighth-seeded Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now emerged victorious in two of their three meetings. In his post-match interview, Melzer attributed his success to a well-crafted game plan and flawless execution. MPs, led by the Lords' Reform Group, have proposed a comprehensive plan to reform the House of Lords by introducing a smaller, elected second chamber, with 70% of its members elected by the people. The plan aims to increase the pressure on Tony Blair to reform the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller upper chamber in which 70% of its members would be chosen by the public. MPs and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999 when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. The group believes it can win support for removing the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government has postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers because they said they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has argued that there needs to be consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions that there will be proposals for changing at least the powers of the Lords in Labour's manifesto.

After a solid debut on the international circuit, Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jos M. Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equalled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final, having won his heat in 7.64 seconds but running 0.04 seconds slower than his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

A US woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP), claiming that its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a specific date. The unnamed woman from Georgia alleges that a chip inside the cartridge informs the printer that it needs re-filling, even when it does not. The lawsuit aims to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer company, has declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges employ a chip technology to detect when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a replacement. However, the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of whether they are empty.

Virgin Radio is set to become the world's first 3G broadcast station, partnering with technology firm Sydus to broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. The radio station, through its partnership with Sydus, will offer a unique listening experience, allowing users to tune in to their favorite stations on the go. According to James Cridland, Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, "this marks radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station to be made available, followed by two digital stations, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Cridland added, "this application will enable anyone, anywhere to listen to Virgin Radio, simply by having the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music is thrilled to announce its appearance at the Isle of Wight Music Festival in June, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. The band has already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, taking place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzurana, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take to the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's "Virginia Plain," with other hits including "Street Life," "Love is the Drug," and the 1981 John Lennon cover, "Jealous Guy.

Captain Brian O'Driscoll, one of Ireland's six nations captains, is set to lead the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid match on March 5. Joining him are France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami in the Northern Party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a Tsumani fund-raising match at Twickenham. 'I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players,' he said. This will be a chance for Woodward to assess some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. 'The game promises to be a great spectacle,' he said.

Spirit Awards Hails Sideways as the comedy that has dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. Sideways was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne took home the Best Director and Best Screenplay awards, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. The film also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. Sideways is tipped to do well at the Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, are given to films made outside the traditional studio system, and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who took Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama Maria Full of Grace. Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for Maria Full of Grace.

Prince, the self-proclaimed "top music earner" in 2004, dominated the charts by earning more than any other pop star, surpassing Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer's successful musicology tour and album sales generated a staggering $56.5 million (30.4 million), with a significant portion coming from his concert and publishing deals. Madonna, who was a close second, earned a respectable $54.9 million (29.5 million) from her global re-invention tour. Simon and Garfunkel, who made a successful comeback, took the 10th spot, with their reunion tour generating $24.9 million (13.4 million) last year. According to the magazine, Prince's return to the spotlight after a decade-long hiatus was a major highlight of the year. His 2004 tour, which grossed a whopping $90.3 million (48.5 million), was a testament to his enduring popularity, with over 1.9 million copies of his album Musicology being sold

Wal-Mart takes a stand against two major US brands, launching advertising campaigns to set the record straight about their products and corporate behavior. The world's largest retailer, Wal-Mart, has taken out more than 100 full-page ads in national newspapers. The company is seeking to dispel criticism over pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, the drug company Eli Lilly is planning a campaign against "false" claims about its product Prozac. Wal-Mart kicked off the battle with ads in newspapers like The Wall Street Journal, using an open letter from company President Lee Scott, stating that it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth". "There are a lot of 'urban legends' going around these days about Wal-Mart, but facts are facts.

Conservatives unveil plans to devolve policing powers to local communities, allowing them to elect their own area police commissioners. Under the proposals, local authorities would assume responsibility for managing their own police forces, replacing the current "faceless" police structures. The Conservative Party's leader, Michael Howard, emphasized that the new system would not supersede the role of a chief constable, ensuring that the operational independence of police forces is maintained. The Liberal Democrats, however, expressed concerns that the plans could lead to extreme political groups exerting undue influence over policing, while Labour Party critics branded the Conservative Party's promises as "extravagant" and "undemocratic." The Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, stressed the importance of retaining operational independence, with its chairman, Jan Berry, warning that the plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what happens on the ground, describing it as "a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches.

At a glance, the UK opposition has unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan  individuals coming to live and work in the UK from outside the EU will be subject to health checks if they plan to stay six months or more. Those from countries with a high incidence of TB will be required to undergo a chest X-ray and further tests if deemed necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union who plan to stay a year or more will be required to undergo a comprehensive medical examination, including tests for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive test for TB would automatically result in visa applications being rejected. All other conditions will be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

The Welsh hopes of a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris have been raised. Can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? Those are the two questions occupying not just Wales supporters, but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in". A crestfallen French coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed  "There was a French half and there was a Welsh half."

Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart with their latest release, securing the number one spot, surpassing flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters. This marks a triumphant debut for the trio, following the success of their single "Black and White Town", which reached number six. Meanwhile, R&B star Nelly has claimed the top spot on the singles chart with "Over and Over", a collaboration with Tim McGraw. Other notable new entries in the top ten include Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs, as well as Futureheads and Usher. The latest re-release of Elvis Presley's "Elvis" (formerly known as "Marie's the Name"), his latest flame, has entered the chart at number three, narrowly missing out on the top spot by one position to Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up". Hip-hop artist Akon's "Locked Up" has landed at number five, while Leeds-based band Kaiser Chiefs have secured their second chart hit with "Oh My God" at number six.

Mefin Davies, a key player for Wales, is poised to remain with English Premiership side Gloucester, despite reported interest from the Ospreys. According to BBC Wales, the Ospreys are keen on securing the 32-year-old hooker's services, but Davies is reportedly inclined to stay with his current team. Having played a starring role in Wales' RBS Six Nations victory over England on Saturday, Davies' impressive form has likely earned him a new contract with Gloucester, with whom he is currently on a one-year deal. The hooker's journey to Gloucester was marked by a tumultuous period following the demise of the Celtic Warriors region, which left him without a professional contract. He subsequently joined Neath RFC on a semi-professional basis before being granted match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management. Although he expressed frustration with his treatment at the time, Davies has since thrived at Gloucester, solidifying his position within the team.

The government is facing growing anger from local ministers over plans to allocate whitehall cash to keep council tax bills low. According to Nick Raynsford, the local government minister, he has held "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers regarding the matter. The reallocation of 512m from central to local government budgets, as outlined in his pre-budget report on Thursday, is part of a 1bn package aimed at helping English local authorities keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, which is likely to be a key issue in the upcoming general election. Mr. Raynsford emphasized that nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in ensuring the smooth running of local authorities, which are responsible for delivering essential services without significant council tax increases.

Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin, a trailblazing Arab football club from Israel, is set to make history by becoming the first Arab side to compete in the UEFA Cup, with four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, ready to don the team's jersey. The squad will face English Premier League giants Newcastle United in the first round, a monumental challenge for the underdog Israeli club. Notably, Murambadoro, who gained recognition for his impressive performance at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, played a crucial role in Bnei Sakhnin's 6-1 thrashing of Albanian side Partizani Tirana in the previous round. The 28-year-old goalkeeper recently joined the club after a brief stint with South African outfit Hellas Hellas, and his arrival has bolstered the team's chances of success.
